hat if we didn’t wait for a eu- logy to say what matters? WWhat if gratitude, honour and affection were spoken aloud while people could still hear them, laugh at them, maybe even argue with them? Across the world, many cultures have quietly answered that question. Long be- fore wellness hashtags and mindfulness apps, societies found ways to celebrate people not after they’re gone, but while they’re still living, breathing, arguing, loving and changing. These traditions aren’t always loud or festive. Some are subtle, some deeply emotional, others joyful to the point of being noisy. But they all share a simple idea. Life deserves acknowledgement before the final good- bye.
The urge to honour the living In many modern societies, celebration is oddly postponed. We wait for mile- stones, anniversaries, retirement parties. Or worse, we wait until someone dies to speak about their impact. Funerals be- come the space where love finally gets articulated. Anthropologists often point out that this delay isn’t universal.
